webTitle: Barclays sued by New York attorney general over alleged 'dark pool' fraud

fields.bodyText: The New York attorney general has sued Barclays, accusing the British bank of misrepresenting the safety of its US-based alternative trading system, or "dark pool", to investors. Eric Schneiderman said on Wednesday that contrary to its own assurances the bank had operated its dark pool system to favor high-frequency traders – firms that use complex computer systems to buy and sell huge volumes of stocks in milliseconds to take advantage of often tiny movements in share prices. “The facts alleged in our complaint show that Barclays demonstrated a disturbing disregard for its investors in a systematic pattern of fraud and deceit,” Schneiderman said. “Barclays grew its dark pool by telling investors they were diving into safe waters. According to the lawsuit, Barclays’ dark pool was full of predators – there at Barclays’ invitation.” Schneiderman is currently conducting a sweeping investigation into broker-run trading systems known as dark pools at a time when some experts calculate high-frequency trading accounts for the majority of US stock market trading. Scrutiny of the practice intensified following the March release of best-selling author Michael Lewis' book, Flash Boys: A Wall Street Revolt, which argues that high-frequency traders have rigged the stock market by taking advantage of systems unavailable to others. Barclays' dark pool, LX, was the second largest alternative trading system in the US for the week of 2 June, according to data from the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, trading more than 282m shares during the period. Schneiderman alleges that Barclays made false claims about the extent and type of high-frequency trading in its dark pool. In one example he said the bank removed the name of a high-frequency trading firm, then the fund’s largest participant, from its marketing material. The attorney general claims the bank knew the trader engaged in predatory behavior. In response to the change, Schneiderman said, one employee stated: “I had always liked the idea that we were being transparent, but happy to take liberties if we can all agree.” “Barclays heavily promoted a service called Liquidity Profiling, which Barclays claimed was a ‘surveillance’ system that tracked every trade in Barclays’ dark pool in order to identify predatory traders, rate them based on the objective characteristics of their trading behavior, and hold them accountable for engaging in predatory practices,” Schneiderman’s office said in a statement. Contrary to those promises, the attorney general alleges that: Barclays has never prohibited any trader from participating in its dark pool, regardless of how predatory its activity was determined to be. Barclays did not regularly update the ratings of high-frequency trading firms monitored by Liquidity Profiling. Barclays “overrode” certain Liquidity Profiling ratings – including for some of its own internal trading desks that engaged in high-frequency trading – by assigning safe ratings to traders that were otherwise determined to be toxic. Contrary to Barclays’ claims that it protects clients from aggressive or predatory high-frequency trading in its dark pool, Schneiderman alleges that Barclays operates its dark pool to favor high-frequency traders and has given them systematic advantages over others trading in the pool in order to attract them. Schneiderman said the investigation was aided significantly by a number of former Barclays’ employees. Barclays was not immediately available for comment.

webTitle: RBA member argues it's far from doom and gloom after mining boom

fields.standfirst: Former Keating adviser John Edwards is an optimistic beacon in an otherwise dark sky
fields.body:
Gloominess is often considered a prerequisite to becoming an economist. But John Edwards, a former adviser to Paul Keating and now a board member of the Reserve Bank, has a rather optimistic take on Australia’s situation.

In his new Lowy Institute paper, Beyond the Boom, published on Wednesday by Penguin Australia, he argues the mining boom did not have as big an impact as people think and that the end of the investment side of the boom need not mean Australia descends into recession.

Edwards believes that Australians have a bit of false nostalgia for not only the 1980s and the economic reforms conducted during the Hawke-Keating years, but also for the mining boom of the early- to mid-2000s.

In March, while speaking at the Wheeler Centre, he argued “we cannot reproduce” the big reforms of the 1980s and 1990s: “You can’t cut tariffs twice; you can’t move from a very highly centralised wage determination system to enterprise bargaining twice; you can’t float [the dollar] twice”.

Moreover, Edwards, in his paper, argues that economic reform in the past decade has not “been entirely neglected, as is often alleged”. He lists among the recent reforms: the GST; creating “a national industrial relations system”; changes to the funding of “schools, vocational and higher education”; implementing “with little fuss a vast migration program”, and carrying out “useful, though largely unrecognised, reforms to minimise differences in state regulatory structures”.

To this list he adds the introduction of “a super profits tax on mining and a tax on industrial carbon emissions” … “with all their imperfections, and against determined opposition”.

But where Edwards is most at odds with a number of his contemporaries, such as his fellow former ALP government adviser, Ross Garnaut, is his view that the mining boom was not that big a deal and thus its end (or at least the end of the investment stage) is not as dire as some might fear.

To support this claim, he notes that “Australian output grew faster in the 10 years before the mining boom began than it has since. Incomes and employment rose just as much before as after”.

And certainly if we look at the decade before 2002 compared with the 10 years after 2002, Australia’s GDP, GDP per capita, national income and productivity all grew faster in the decade before the mining boom than the decade after it began:

Only employment grew faster in the decade after 2002. Edwards argues that far from mining being the big driver of the economy, “it is only recently, 10 years after the boom was said to have begun, that actual mining output has begun to increase significantly faster than gross domestic product (GDP)”.

Again, if we observe the gross value added of mining since 1992, the increase until 2011 is quite linear. It is only after 2011 that we see a significant surge:

Similarly, from June 1992 to June 2002 mining gross value added contributed 2.9 percentage points to Australia’s GDP – the same as it did from June 2002 to June 2012. We see this even more clearly when we look at mining gross value added as a percentage of Australia’s GDP:

But what the mining boom did bring was revenue. Revenue which since the GFC and since the cuts to income taxes made from 2004 to 2008 has faded:

A couple weeks ago, Edwards suddenly became Joe Hockey’s favourite economist from the Labor side of politics. This was because Edwards said in the Australian Financial Review recently that “I’ve no doubt there is a budget crisis”.

The treasurer took delight in telling parliament that Edwards said Australia’s government debt “in absolute terms [is] absolutely astronomical compared to far more serious episodes in Australian history, including recoveries from serious recessions”.

Except Hockey failed to tell parliament that Edwards thinks about five-sixths of Australia’s budget crisis is on the revenue side. Far from needing to cut government spending, he advocates increasing taxes – and primarily income tax.

In March, he suggested that it was “quite obvious” that “the solution is going to be on the revenue side – specifically on the income-tax side”. He argued that “in fact we will bring the federal budget back into surplus by leaving tax rates unchanged, and allowing incomes to grow across the existing tax rates. This seems to be a solution to the problem that is not only desirable but investable”.

This is perhaps not the kind of talk that had Hockey telling parliament that Edwards was “someone in the Labor party that understands economics” and that members of the ALP “should all learn from him”.

Similarly Edwards’s optimism for the future does not square with the fear tactics employed by the government in the past months.

Far from suggesting the mining boom is over, and with it our economic prosperity, Edwards suggests “in some important respects, [the mining boom] has barely begun”.

He notes, though, that it will be a different boom, one that shifts from being “about investment in mines, and high prices for iron ore and coal” to, “within another year or two”, being about liquid natural gas. And, in this boom, he argues that “Japan and South Korea will be as important as China”.

Edwards does see challenges ahead. He believes we need to take advantage of China’s shift towards services and consumption. He argues Australia needs “to expand the range of its regional exports to include more intermediate goods and services integrated into regional production chains, as well as food, tourism and education”.

Among the steps needed to achieve this, he argues, is placing “more attention to the quality of the public service; the quality of teaching; the quality of leadership in government and business, and to the education and training of the workforce”.

Edwards is not a Pollyanna who thinks Australia can just put up its feet and reap economic windfalls. But it is refreshing to see an economist argue about the challenges ahead from a point of optimism, rather than with fear and negativity.

• This article was amended on 27 June 2014. The original article said Beyond the Boom would be released next week.

webTitle: US music licensing laws 'arcane and dysfunctional,' says RIAA chairman

fields.standfirst:
Industry leaders fought for changes to American copyright law at House judiciary hearing, part of US copyright law review

  • Music copyright: 'just a bunch of people fighting over money'
fields.body:
Music industry leaders fought for changes to American copyright law at a House judiciary meeting on Wednesday, telling lawmakers how the complicated licensing system challenges their ability – and that of music creators – to make money.

Nearly all of the nine witnesses on Wednesday called for an overhaul of current music licensing law, including Cary Sherman, chairman and CEO of the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA), who described the current system for licensing as “antiquated, inefficient and frankly, broken” and “arcane and complex and dysfunctional.” Sherman called for a holistic solution to the laws instead of piecemeal changes to current licensing standards.

The hearing was part of a congressional review of US copyright law that is especially interested in reviewing music licensing laws, which are considered archaic by many in the industry, and were most recently amended in 1998 with the Digital Millennium Copyright Act.

Music licensing laws are primarily rooted in the pre-digital era, and how an artist gets paid depends on a number of factors including whether the artist wrote the song or performed it, recorded the song before 1972, and if the song was played on CD, AM/FM radio or streaming services like Pandora and Spotify. Those decisions, of course, have direct connections to how much money each of the groups testifying on Wednesday can make.

“We’ll probably get you all to agree two days after the sun rises in the west,” said congressman Jim Sensenbrenner, facing representatives of industry groups including the RIAA, the National Association of Broadcasters (NAB), the Radio Music License Committee (RMLC) and the American Society of Composers.

While digital streaming services are often made the enemy in these discussions, at Wednesday’s hearing, witnesses besieged AM/FM radio – which does not have to pay performance rights. Radio stations were initially able to avoid paying these rights because radio plays could be considered promotional, but the continued existence of this standard lead copyright office head Maria Pallante to call the practice “indefensible” in a March 2013 testimony.

Non-profit licensing group SoundExchange, the RIAA, and the American Association of Independent Music (AAIM) piled on criticism of AM/FM radio for not being required to pay these royalties. However, Ed Christian, chairman of the Radio Music License Committee (RMLC), said the industry he represents was being scapegoated. "The radio industry is not some vast pot of riches that can be tapped as a bailout for the recording industry," said Christian.

Internet radio, along with other online streaming services, was also heavily criticized in the discussions because they are not required to pay performance royalties for recordings made before 15 February 1972, which means that Aretha Franklin does not get paid when Respect is played on digital streaming services. Songwriters of the pre-1972 songs do get a royalty payment, but Pandora and SiriusXM have faced several lawsuits over this standard.

“In short, demanding payment now for what radio has never, in 100 years, had to pay for will merely create a windfall that the artists did not expect when they created the works,” said David J Frear, executive vice-president and chief financial officer of Sirius XM. “Sirius XM, by contrast, will be confronted with tens of millions of dollars in a new, unforeseen and significant payment obligation that was not part of the rights framework in place when it started its business – money that will no longer be available for improving our products and services, innovating, or hiring new employees.”

Pallante has shown interest in revising music licensing laws, which is encouraging to stakeholders and observers, but others feel that congress is unlikely to enact any change. David Maddox, an attorney and professor at Belmont University’s Curb College of Entertainment and Music Business, said that when it does happen, it will likely benefit the powerful associations like those speaking at Wednesday’s hearing.

“Like it always has been, it’s going to be the big players, that for the most part, call the shots and have the power to get things done,” said Maddox. “That’s the way it’s going to affect the people who are in the major league category – the minor league category are going to have to take what falls from the table.”

webTitle: Bullying payday lender is lucky it wasn't whacked with a huge fine

fields.bodyText: So that's what Wonga meant by "straight talking money". The payday lender was trying to bully errant customers by sending them fake letters from non-existent law firms threatening legal action. Founder Errol Damelin departed Wonga earlier this month, meaning he was not around to issue the grovelling corporate apology. What a shame. It would have been fun to hear him boast one last time about how his payday-lending creation is "transparent" and "responsible". It will cost Wonga £2.6m to compensate 45,000 customers but the company should count itself lucky that it has not been whacked with a huge fine or asked to pay interest at 5,000% on the arrears it extracted via its dodgy dispatches. The letters from "Chainey, D'Amato & Shannon" and "Barker and Lowe Legal Recoveries" were sent in 2008-2010 when the firm was regulated by the old and toothless Office of Fair Trading. The Financial Conduct Authority, which took over the investigation when it came into being last year, has greater powers but naturally is not allowed to use them retrospectively. How big would an FCA fine have been? A punishment of £1,000 a letter might be considered appropriate by a magistrate's court if an individual tried passing himself off as a lawyer with the intention of extracting money. So 45,000 letters would come in at £45m. That punishment would seem about fair. Wonga is a rich company and some of its customers are deemed vulnerable. The FCA did not pursue prosecutions because it judged that achieving compensation for affected individuals was the priority and it did not want to risk delays. That's understandable. But the police will inevitably have to examine a case of possible impersonation of a solicitor: letters do not write themselves.

webTitle: Furious investors attack WPP and RBS over excessive bonuses and pay

fields.bodyText: Investors at two FTSE 100 companies have joined the chorus of protests against excessive executive pay, with nearly 30% of shareholders at the advertising group WPP refusing to endorse a plan that allowed founder Sir Martin Sorrell to receive a £30m windfall last year. Meanwhile, the Royal Bank of Scotland chairman Sir Philip Hampton was forced to defend the bank's bonus schemes, admitting: "Pay in the financial sector, particularly banks, got out of line with other sectors and more importantly the underlying performance of the business. "Ultimately taxpayers picked up some of the bills for that." The rebellion at WPP's annual shareholder meeting suggests that departing chairman Philip Lader has yet to quell a rebellion that began in 2012. In arrangements described by the influential advisory group Pirc as excessive, Sorrell is expected to collect nearly £100m over the next three years in share awards from long term schemes that were halted in 2012 but have yet to expire. In addition, he will be entitled to earn a maximum of £19.3m a year in 2014 and 2015, under a new scheme introduced last year. Votes cast before the meeting at London's Shard skyscraper showed over 28% of shareholders rejected or abstained from approving the 2013 pay plan, up from 26% the year before. In a separate poll on the three year pay policy introduced in 2013, the first binding vote under new city rules, 26% voted against or abstained. However, in order to pass a resolution, companies need a simple majority of votes cast, and WPP secured approval from nearly 82% of shareholders excluding abstentions for its pay policy. "There have been some considerable concessions about executive remuneration at WPP over the last few years but the company still maintains a complex assortment of pay arrangements," said Pirc representative Andrew Whiley at the meeting. "Will the board consider making all of the variable pay arrangements much more simple, transparent, and easier for shareholders to get a handle on?" Because WPP has not cancelled legacy pay schemes, which will make up the bulk of Sorrell's earnings over the coming years, Pirc argues the company is running six separate plans, all of which have different rules. Awards under WPP's contentious leadership equity acquisition plan (Leap) will continue until 2016. This is because the scheme ran until 2012, but executives are not able to claim their shares for five years. By 2016, Sorrell is expected to receive 7.8m shares from Leap, worth £97.5m at Wednesday's £12.52 share price. Lader responded: "We admit complexity but hope you see our commitment to transparency," adding that cancelling earlier plans would be unfair and could raise legal issues. Private shareholder Keith Jago took the floor at the meeting to say Sorrell's £30m earnings last year were equivalent to £24,000 for every working hour. He also questioned the chief executive's benefits, which included a £167,000 travel allowance for his wife Cristiana Sorrell, an organiser of the World Economic Forum at Davos. "I wonder how anyone can be wroth £30m when the UK is debating over minimum wage levels," said Jago. He also questioned the company's tax haven registration in Jersey. "Personally I don't want to be part of a company that behaves like that. Are we of the same ilk as Amazon or Starbucks?" WPP paid £240m around the world in corporation tax last year, according to finance director Paul Richardson, and over £150m in the UK in various taxes. Following the collapse of a merger between American rival Omnicom and France's Publicis, WPP remains by some margin the largest marketing group in the world, accounting for at least a quarter of global media spend. Sorrell pointed out that £1,000 invested when the company was founded in 1985 would be wroth £47,900 today. The same sum invested in the FTSE 250 over that period would be worth just £4,250. webTitle: Business leaders must take blame for losing popularity, says Sainsbury's boss

fields.standfirst: Justin King, who quits as supermarket's chief next month, says companies need to raise the bar when it comes to citizenship
fields.body:
The business community must take full responsibility for losing its standing in society over tax avoidance and working conditions, according to Sainsbury's outgoing chief executive Justin King.

King, who steps down from the supermarket in two weeks,said shoppers would deliver the ultimate judgment on companies that dodge taxes or treat staff poorly.

He also told the MT Live conference in London that simply obeying the law was not enough for businesses to count themselves as good citizens and urged other business leaders not to shy away from criticising companies that are out of line.

"Part of the problem is that there's been one element of the business community with the attitude 'nobody loves us but we don't care'. Certainly there was some of that with the banks."

King added: "How can business stand up and say we obey the laws and say that conveys good citizenship? That's what you are required to do. What conveys good citizenship is what you do beyond the law and I don't think we have done enough on that."

King said the issue of tax was a good example where shoppers were speaking loud and clear about what they wanted to see. "Sainsbury's is the seventh-biggest taxpayer in the UK bar none, not including the tax our employees pay. If we have to compete with businesses that do not contribute to our society in the same way, that's a consumer issue. Whether it be business rates or taxation. The great thing is that consumers sort it."

He said the recent decision of Starbucks to relocate its European headquarters to the UK after consumer protests over tax was a great example of shoppers driving change by choosing to buy their coffee in a place where the company paid UK taxes. "The power of the consumer wallet is more powerful than the vote," he said.

King gave no hints about his plans for the future other than saying he wanted to do "something different", which may be bad news for some Marks & Spencer shareholders who would like to see him return there.

In a typically self-confident analogy, King compared himself to the England striker turned TV pundit Gary Lineker. "Gary got it right. He went when he was pretty much at the height of his powers. There were still records to be broken and goals to be scored but he went when there was still a clear sense that there was an opportunity to go on and do something else."

King said he would never criticise his successor, Mike Coupe, in the way former Tesco boss Sir Terry Leahy and former Morrisons boss Sir Ken Morrison have done recently: "The day I go, I have to go," King said.

King plans to head to Brazil to watch the World Cup final after he steps down on 10 July. Insisting he was leaving the business in great hands, King said he was sure Sainsbury's was in a much better place than when he arrived a decade ago.

He said his driving thought had been his mother. "When I arrived at Sainsbury's my mum touched my arm and said 'Are you sure darling? I shop there every week and it's shit.'"

He said that kind of loyal customer who wanted the store to do better had been the driving force behind what he had tried to achieve at the supermarket. "I have run the business entirely for my mum as a customer for ten years," King said.

webTitle: UK government tells retailers to pay up in Rana Plaza compensation battle

fields.bodyText: The government is weighing into the battle for compensation for victims of last year's Rana Plaza factory collapse in Bangladesh with a letter warning British retailers including Matalan to pay up. The cut-price clothing chain, based in Skelmersdale, Lancashire, has admitted that its clothes had been produced on the second floor of the factory building, where over 1,100 people died, but has refused to pay into a compensation fund backed by the International Labour Organisation. The company says it was not using Rana Plaza when the building collapsed and has insisted that it has already helped victims with a donation to a charity support programme to mothers involved in the disaster. Alan Duncan, the international development minister, said he is writing personally to a number of retailers, understood to include Matalan, as he was alarmed that a number had not made any contribution to the ILO fund. Workers' rights campaigners say the type of charity scheme Matalan has paid into does not provide full compensation for loss of earnings by injured workers and the families of those who died. They want Matalan to pay £3m into the ILO fund that remains less than halfway to its $40m (£24m) target more than a year after the disaster. Although Duncan refused to name the companies he has written to, his action marks the first time a government minister has put pressure on individual retailers over payments into the compensation fund. It comes after Frances O'Grady, the TUC general secretary, called on the government to pressure UK companies sourcing from Bangladesh to pay up. To date, $17.1m has been donated or pledged to the compensation fund. Victims have received a first tranche of cash, but there are fears that additional payments will be cut short if further donations by retailers are not forthcoming. "We have to raise the pressure over a year after the event to make sure a complete compensation package is assembled," Duncan said. He added that retailers could not claim that they weren't aware of where their clothes were produced because production had been sub-contracted by their suppliers. Duncan's intervention comes after Jenny Willott, the consumer affairs minister, said retailers must have a policy on sourcing ethical products, because ignoring consumers' concerns about forced labour and dangerous working conditions could risk putting them out of business. In the wake of a Guardian investigation which found prawns sold in the UK were produced with the help of slave labour, she ordered the British Retail Consortium to produce new guidance urging its members to improve transparency about human rights abuses linked to food, drink, clothing and other products. Duncan's intervention also comes ahead of a high-level international meeting in Paris at the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development that will discuss global efforts to build more responsible supply chains in the wake of the Rana Plaza disaster.

webTitle: Marks & Spencer asbestos case: 'I feel so angry and betrayed'

fields.standfirst: After her former employer admits negligence, cancer patient Janice Allen explains how her perception of the firm is destroyed
fields.body:
Janice Allen sits in the conservatory in her cosy semi-detached house in Harrow, husband Stuart alongside her, explaining how their lives have been devastated after she was diagnosed with the deadly cancer mesothelioma, caused by being exposed to asbestos when she worked at Marks & Spencer up to 36 years ago.

Her lawyer, Harminder Bains of Leigh Day, who took on the legal claim in which M&S have admitted breaching their duty of care to Allen, is warning that many more hard-working, as yet oblivious members of the public could comprise a "third phase" of people stricken by exposure to asbestos. Bains says that inadequate safety procedures, in breach of the strict law on asbestos-handing and removal, means the public must have been exposed. First of all, industrial and construction workers handled asbestos when it was considered an invaluable fire-proof material until its dangers were recognised in the 1970s, before maintenance workers were exposed in those buildings.

"Before this happened," Allen says, "I had never heard of mesothelioma, I barely knew about asbestos. I never would have dreamed that I would be affected by it. It has been devastating."

She and Stuart met when they both worked at M&S; he was 18, she 19, his supervisor on the men's shirts section of the flagship Oxford Street store in London near Marble Arch. They recall working hard, being made to feel part of an M&S family, that the company cared. Thursdays were late-night shopping and pay day, and they would often go to the pub, the Marlborough Head, after work. Janice, now 53, worked for nine years, 1988-87, at Marble Arch then M&S in Uxbridge until they had their first child, Matthew, now 26, then their daughter, Louise, now 24. Stuart stayed at M&S for 22 years, working his way up to becoming a business analyst, until he left in 2001.

"Marks & Spencer engender this complete loyalty; they had welfare for staff, hairdressing, when they celebrated 100 years as a company [in 1984] we were all given books on the history," Janice says. "Now I feel so angry and betrayed. To know that behind the scenes it is so cynical they did not even care for the health and safety of their own employees – it is beyond words. I was only 18 when I joined, I thought I had a secure job, and now every day I wish I could turn the clock back and had never, ever gone to work for them."

After the children went to school, Janice herself worked in schools, latterly as a higher level teaching assistant for secondary school children with special educational needs, a job she loved. She and Stuart were looking forward to a little more comfort, and holidays, in the forthcoming years, but the end of their plans came after Janice woke up one morning in the summer of 2012 with agonising pain in her ribs. It was, she says, "like a shard of glass going through my muscle".

The pain eased for several months, until in March 2013 the agony returned. She went through a series of tests and X-rays, until in April 2013 she was diagnosed with mesothelioma. It is a cancer in the outer lining of the lung, caused from cells forming around asbestos, possibly just a single deadly fibre, which can have been inhaled decades before.

"It has been devastating, the shock of the diagnosis," Janice says. "It was disbelief, at how this could happen, and to realise it is not curable, although it is treatable – I am having to hang on to that. My first reactions were to go completely into depression and extreme anxiety. Without the help of Macmillan nurses and the hospital, I would be having terrible trouble functioning normally now."

She did not think for some time about suing M&S, but through her stepmother, she heard about Marks & Spencer having been prosecuted, for illegally unsafe handling of asbestos at the Reading store, for which the firm was fined £1m in 2011, and sued by former employees, in cases which settled rather than reached a judgment.

Bains, an asbestos specialist, applied for a court order that M&S disclose documents relating to the Marble Arch and Uxbridge stores where Janice Allen worked, including surveys of the stores which would show the prevalence of asbestos. M&S did not disclose the documents. But in April M&S formally admitted in court that it: "In breach of duty, exposed [Janice Allen] to asbestos fibres, during the course of her employment with them." The company declined to comment on its breach of duty to Allen, but stressed it took place in the 1970s and 80s.

In a statement the company said: "We are confident that we now have the most rigorous policy we can have in place and that M&S stores are safe for our employees and our customers."

That admission does raise the alarming possibility that in the past, many other people, in places as public as M&S's large stores, may have contracted the deadly disease previously associated with unfortunate industrial and maintenance workers.

"I hope my case will bring some attention on to this," Allen says. "When we understood how much asbestos there was, the degree of risk we were exposed to, we felt so angry. Throughout our time, nobody ever said anything about it."

webTitle: Marks & Spencer admits exposing employee to asbestos

fields.standfirst: Retailer agrees to pay damages to Janice Allen, a staff member for nine years who now has incurable form of lung cancer
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer has admitted negligently exposing to asbestos a woman who worked in two of its stores.

Janice Allen, 53, who was a supervisor in the men's and women's clothes sections of M&S from 1978-87, first at its main Oxford Street store in London and then in Uxbridge, has been diagnosed with mesothelioma, a lethal form of lung cancer caused by inhaling asbestos fibres. There is no cure, and she has been given months to live. M&S has agreed in the high court to pay "significant'' damages after judgment in her favour in May. M&S admitted breaching its legal duty of care .

Allen's lawyer, Harminder Bains, of Leigh Day, said there could be many people suffering asbestos-related diseases caused by owners of premises failing to comply with legal safety procedures.

Mesothelioma, cancer of the lung's outer lining, can take decades to develop and causes a drawn-out, painful death.

Allen, married with two children in their 20s, said she was "devastated and distraught" that she was dying from a cancer she had never heard of, from inhaling asbestos that she did not know existed in the stores.

"I feel betrayed by Marks & Spencer. The company used to portray itself like a family; they engendered loyalty. I worked very hard, I met my husband there. We were looking forward to enjoying life in the coming years; instead I have to face the fact I will not live to see my grandchildren."

Asbestos was considered a miracle fire-proof building material and widely used in construction after the second world war until the 1970s, when it was recognised to be lethal. Successive legislation has since required the removal of asbestos.

In 2013 Steve Rowe, an M&S executive director, told a BBC documentary: "If you look back into the 60s, 70s and 80s, it is possible that staff were exposed to asbestos in our stores." But M&S's policies relating to asbestos had become "industry leading" since then.

In 2011, M&S was fined £1m, for unsafe handling of asbestos at its Reading store. The judge Harvey Clarke QC said managers had been cavalier in not closing the store while the work was ongoing, "to keep the trading profit as high as reasonably possible".

Allen worked in the Marble Arch store and then at Uxbridge for a total of nine years after leaving school at 18. He said the air-conditioning was likely to have circulated asbestos dust, and staff and the public could have been exposed in other ways unless strict measures were followed.

webTitle: Primark denies purchasing clothes made in forced labour camps or prisons

fields.standfirst: Response made after Northern Ireland shopper says she found message from Chinese dissident inside their trousers
fields.body:
Primark has denied it purchases clothing made in forced labour camps or prisons in China in response to claims by a Northern Ireland shopper that she found a message from a Chinese dissident inside trousers bought in one of the company's stores.

Amnesty International said a local woman has handed it a secret note inside a pair of trousers she claimed was from a Chinese worker held in a forced labour camp.

The human rights organisation said the woman took her story to them after she allegedly found the message secreted in a pair of Primark trousers.

Primark said that while it would investigate her claims there was no evidence any of their clothes are made from slave labour in Chinese gulags.

Primark said: "These three-quarter crop trousers were last ordered by Primark in early 2009 and were last sold in Northern Ireland in October 2009. We find it very strange that this has come to light so recently, given that the trousers were on sale four years ago.

"We will be contacting the customer to obtain the trousers, so we can investigate how this occurred and whether there are issues which need to be looked into.

"Nine inspections of the supplier have been carried out by Primark's ethical standards team since 2009. To be clear, no prison or other forced labour of any kind was found during these inspections.

"Primark is committed to making working conditions safer for those who manufacture its products. It was the first UK retailer to sign the accord on fire and building safety in Bangladesh in order to work collaboratively with other brands and stakeholders in the industry to bring about sustainable long-term change in the country."

The shopper, Karen Wisínska who lives in County Fermanagh, said she bought the trousers from the Primark store in central Belfast in June 2011 but only discovered the communication from the dissident when she recently went to retrieve the item from a cupboard at her home.

The writer claims to be a prisoner in the Xiang Nan prison in Hubei province and forced to work 15 hours a day. The author of the note goes on to appeal to the international community to condemn the Chinese government for a violation of the prisoner's human rights.

Wisínska said: "I was shocked to find this note and card inside the trousers from Primark and even more shocked to discover that it appears to have been made under slave labour conditions in a Chinese prison. I am only sorry that I did not discover the note when I first purchased the clothing – then I could have brought this scandal to light much earlier."

Amnesty International's Northern Ireland programme director, Patrick Corrigan, said: "It is a horrific tale. It's very difficult to know whether its genuine, but the fear has to be that this is just the tip of the iceberg.

"There is no excuse for any UK company to be profiting from forced labour in Chinese prisons. They should be monitoring their supply chains and terminating contracts when they discover abuses.

"The government should now amend its modern day slavery bill to require companies to keep their supply chains free of such abuses."

The full text of the note translated into English is as follows: "SOS! SOS! SOS! We are prisoners in the Xiang Nan prison of the Hubei province in China. Our job inside the prison is to produce fashion clothes for export. We work 15 hours per day and the food we eat wouldn't even be given to dogs or pigs. We work as hard as oxen in the field. We call on the international community to condemn the Chinese government for the violation of our human rights!"

webTitle: WPP should think twice as to whether smaller pay rebellion is a success

fields.bodyText: WPP will probably regard a 28% rebellion over its pay report, including abstentions, as a half-decent result. There were a few more rebels than last year but a lot fewer than in 2012, when 60% refused to support the pay report and the advertising house was obliged to call a halt to Sir Martin Sorrell's super-charged co-investment scheme. WPP's attitude will be: a majority is a majority, what's the fuss? It is, of course, possible for a company's pay committee to operate this way and to congratulate itself on how its judgments have been "corroborated by the support of a significant majority of share owners," as the current annual report described last year's outcome. Yet the members of the committee, and chief executive Sir Martin Sorrell, should ask themselves why WPP, even after "substantial revisions" to its pay policies, finds itself roughly as popular as Barclays on remuneration. The level of the protest at the bank was 34% this year, even after the decision to pay bigger bonuses to investment bankers in a year of sharply lower profits. WPP, with its vastly better financial performance and share price, only just did better. The explanation is twofold. First, Sorrell's reformed pay arrangements are still vastly over-the-top by the standards of FTSE 100 companies of similar size. The boss will get £7.8m for "on plan" performance this year and can collect almost £20m as a maximum reward. Carrots of that size only exist these days at firms that have decided to adopt a tin ear to the public debate over boardroom pay. The second explanation is that Sorrell gets the chance to earn such rewards while sitting on a mountain of payouts that are yet to vest under his "Leap" – leadership equity acquisition plan – co-investment scheme. When WPP was bounced by the 2012 rebels into stopping new grants under Leap, the company said it would honour all past awards. The relevant table in the annual report shows what Leap, which ran in five-year cycles, could be worth to Sorrell in the next three years. We're talking up to 7.8m shares, worth £96m at current share prices. He is not lacking reasons to be motivated. There's one more cheery fact: a £167,000 allowance for "spousal travel," a real novelty. In the circumstances, it's amazing that these things seem to annoy only one in four WPP shareholders.

webTitle: Bigger than expected 2.9% slump in US economy shocks markets – business live

fields.standfirst:
US GDP shrank annualised 2.9% in first quarter

RBS and WPP face unrest at annual meetings

Wonga to repay customers £2.6m after law firm letters

FTSE 100 falls on US data and Iraq conflict
fields.body:
5.41pm BST

UK Financial Investments Limited which manages the government’s stake in the Royal Bank of Scotland has confirmed it agreed with all resolutions at the annual meeting where it was eligible to vote. It said it supported the re-election of directors and on bonuses it said:

Following a process of thorough engagement with the RBS remuneration committee, UKFI believes the committee has exercised reasonable judgement in relation to their approach to directors’ remuneration, particularly in the context of the challenging year RBS experienced in 2013 and the new strategy as outlined by Ross McEwan earlier this year.

RBS continues to make use of share-based variable awards and applies stringent deferral conditions, which protect the interests of shareholders.

And on that note, it's time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all your comments, and we'll be back tomorrow.

Updated at 5.50pm BST

5.37pm BST

The European Banking Authority - the pan regulator for the EU - has just published its outlook for the sector, 24 hours before the Bank of England puts out its assessment of the risks facing the financial system, writes Jill Treanor.

The EBA's verdict can be found here. The verdict? Improvements to the strength of the banking industry have taken place but there is plenty to be worried about:

• the future profitability of banks: In 2013, the total operating income declined by €10bn (after a decline of €39bn in 2012) and, in the last quarter of 2013, the annual flow of profits declined by 58 % (€54bn)

• looming redress costs for past mistakes

• a need to keep shrinking balance sheets to bolster capital ratios after a €3.4tn reduction since 2011

The EBA concludes that the business models of some banks will find it difficult to survive in the current environment, especially as many of the banks in its sample were providing their shareholders with a return on equity of less than 4%. Shareholders in banks were used to double digit returns on this measure before the crisis.

3.40pm BST

More from the RBS meeting, courtesy Julia Kollewe:

2.59pm BST

At the RBS AGM, Sir Philip Hampton, the chairman, says branch transactions have fallen 30% since 2011 and more closures are on the way.

We still see a major role for branches as places where our customers can interact with our staff on the big life decisions such as taking out a mortgage, starting up their own business, generally planning for their futures and getting on top of their finances.

We know the value of the High Street branch, and RBS will retain a very large branch network across the UK to fulfil that vision. Since 2011, we've invested £130m in refurbishing 680 branches, £70m in the last 12 months alone. We will continue to have more branches than Asda and Sainsbury's stores combined.

But with continued rapid change in the way people choose to bank, there will inevitably be further closures. Where we have to make the difficult decision to close a branch we will tell our staff and customers first and set out what the alternatives are, such as the post office network or mobile vans.

Things don't seem that explosive in the hall so far. Julia Kollewe's progress reports come via Twitter:

Updated at 2.59pm BST

2.13pm BST

Here are some comments on the US GDP figures from Nancy Curtin, chief investment officer at Close Brothers Asset Management. She thinks the economy's unexpectedly large contraction lies behind the steady-does-it stance of Janet Yellen, chair of the Federal Reserve:

The US economy didn’t just grind to a halt in the first quarter - it hit reverse as the polar vortex took its toll. But we can’t judge current growth by looking in the rear-view mirror, and we are unlikely to see investors react strongly to what is now quite a long way behind us. More recent data have pointed to the economy picking up speed. Manufacturing is at a four year high, while the housing market is looking positive once more. It’s clear that growth has gone up through the gears in Q2, and we’ll see this reflected in the next GDP reading.

While the blip shouldn’t be taken as an indication of underlying weakness in the economy, it has impacted monetary policy. Given the sheer scale of the weather-related slowdown, Yellen hasn’t really had the option to change policy in recent months. In the context, any move away either away from tapering or towards tightening would have rung alarm bells for investors, and this won’t change until data has been consistently on trend. We expect ongoing further forward guidance to prevent the eventual normalisation of interest rates from being a bombshell to investors, but a change in policy isn’t likely in the short-term.”

2.05pm BST

Royal Bank of Scotland's annual meeting has just started at the bank's giant Gogarburn HQ.

My colleage Julia Kollewe is in Edinburgh and has filed this brief update on RBS and Scottish independence.

At Royal Bank of Scotland's annual meeting, bosses are likely to be quizzed about executive pay and Scottish independence.

Sir Philip Hampton, the chairman, said the bank continued to maintain a "neutral position" on independence. Scottish voters will decide on Scotland's future on 18 September.

He added: "There is a great deal of uncertainty and we have raised a number of issues in our full year risk disclosures which I am not going to repeat here in detail but cover areas such as our credit rating, tax and regulation."
Hampton said there is no reason to panic even if there is a Yes vote because "there would be a period of time between the referendum and Scotland actually becoming independent when the UK and Scottish governments would enter negotiations". The UK government has indicated that it would take 18 months before Scotland became independent.
Hampton said: "During this transition period, the Bank of England would be lender of last resort to the banking sector and the UK would be the sovereign domicile for RBS."

There are fears for RBS's 3,000 jobs at its Gogarburn headquarters on the outskirts of Edinburgh, if the bank had to move to London. Under EU rules, banks must be based in the same country as most of their business. In the case of RBS, this is England.

RBS employs about 12,000 people in Scotland, out of 70,000 in the UK.

Updated at 2.07pm BST

1.50pm BST

US GDP shrank 2.9% in first quarter, final figure shows

US GDP contracted by an annual rate of 2.9% in the first quarter, official and final figures show. April's first estimate was for shrinkage of 0.1%, making this the biggest downward revision ever, according to Reuters. Economists had expected today's figure to come in at minus 1.7%.

Here's part of Reuters' story:

While the economy's woes have been largely blamed on an unusually cold winter, the magnitude of the revisions suggest other factors at play beyond the weather.

Sharp revisions to GDP numbers are not unusual as the government does not have complete data when it makes its initial and preliminary estimates.

The latest revisions reflect a weaker pace of healthcare spending than previously assumed, which caused a downgrading of the consumer spending estimate. Trade was also a bigger drag on the economy than previously thought.

Data such as employment, manufacturing and services sectors point to a sharp acceleration in growth early in the second quarter. However, the pace of expansion could fall short of expectations, which range as high as a 3.6 percent rate.

Economists estimate severe weather could have slashed as much as 1.5 percentage points from GDP growth in the first quarter. The government, however, gave no details on the impact of the weather.

Here's are some tweets in response:

Updated at 1.53pm BST

1.38pm BST

Shareholders at the WPP AGM are asking questions about Sir Martin Sorrell's pay after a sizable rebellion against the company's remuneration report and policy:

1.35pm BST

In case anyone's forgotten, the Church of England holds an indirect stake in Wonga, the payday lender revealed today to have masqueraded as bogus law firms to put pressure on late payers.

The church still hold the stake even though Justin Welby, the Archbishop of Canterbury, has pledged to put payday lenders out of business by supporting credit unions.

Jill Treanor has written a pithy blog post about the stake, which you can read here.

1.16pm BST

Juliette Garside has tweeted a picture from WPP's AGM to keep us amused:

1.12pm BST

Talk to fund managers and the message is that appetite for flotations is waning after the fervour of the first few months of the year gave way to greater scepticism about the claims of companies and their owners coming to market.

But figures from Dealogic, courtesy of my colleague Jill Treanor, show that the second quarter of the year, which isn't quite over, was a record.

Here are the details:

· UK IPO volume in 2Q 2014 so far stands at $13.9bn via 37 deals, the highest quarterly total on record. Volume is up 97% from 1Q 2014 ($7bn via 20 deals), and has surpassed the previous quarterly record of $9.0bn (50 deals) set in 4Q 2006

· AA plc’s IPO on June 23rd is the largest UK ECM deal to price so far this quarter, raising $2.4bn via Cenkos Securities plc. This is the largest UK Auto/Truck ECM deal on record, and the largest EMEA Auto/Truck IPO deal since Tognum AG’s $2.7bn listing in June 2007 via Deutsche Bank and Goldman Sachs

· Finance issuers lead UK IPO volume in 2Q 2014 so far with a 21% market share ($2.9bn via nine deals), the highest quarterly volume for the sector since 4Q 2006 ($5.0bn via 19 deals). Retail follows with an 18.5% market share ($2.6bn via four deals), the second largest quarterly total on record for the sector behind $3.1bn via six deals in 1Q 2014

o Pricing on May 23rd, Saga plc’s $928m IPO via Citigroup, Bank of America Merrill Lynch, Credit Suisse, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan and UBS is the eighth largest UK Finance IPO on record

· Cenkos Securities plc leads the UK IPO bookrunner ranking in 2014 YTD with a 12.5% market share, followed by JPMorgan and Bank of America Merrill Lynch with 9.8% and 8.2%, respectively

1.02pm BST

AbbVie, the US drugmaker that is trying to buy London-listed Shire, has set out its case for the proposed £27bn deal.

AbbVie said its cash-and-shares offer represented "compelling" immediate value with significant future potential for gains from ownership in the enlarged group. It said the transaction, which includes rebasing AbbVie in the UK for tax purposes, was "highly executable". Shire has said there are risks attached to the so-called tax inversion ploy, which would help AbbVie avoid tax in the US.

The proposed combination is strategically compelling to AbbVie and Shire and would create a larger and more diversified biopharmaceutical company with multiple leading franchises and significant financial capacity for future acquisitions, investment and enhanced shareholder distributions and value creation.

The US company also sought to persuade Shire shareholders that the part of the proposed deal paid in AbbVie shares was a good deal. AstraZeneca of the UK was able to fend off a takeover approach from Pfizer partly because it convinced shareholders that Pfizer had few growth prospects on its own.

AbbVie stock has meaningful upside independent of a transaction - AbbVie believes that irrespective of a combination with Shire, its stock has potential for meaningful appreciation, driven by strong fundamental performance, a robust pipeline, top-tier EPS growth and strong cash flows.

12.45pm BST

More on the WPP result from our Juliette Garside here:

12.43pm BST

The shareholder revolt at WPP's AGM has come in as expected. Nearly 30% of votes failed to back both the remuneration report and the future pay policy. Let's hope there are some good questions on the subject.

12.41pm BST

WPP's annual meeting has kicked off at the Shard in London and the advertising company has published opening remarks by Phil Lader, its chairman.

On a comparable basis, revenues were up 7.6% in the first five months of the year. This year is expected to be another strong one after a record 2014, he said.

There's no reference to the pay of Sir Martin Sorrell, the chief executive, which is expected to trigger a shareholder rebellion when the votes are counted.

Instead, Lader is fed up that his employees don't get the credit they deserve:

I believe there are still businesses that still see creativity as little more than a cosmetic: a final touch of lipstick to make a product look more appealing. They are profoundly wrong: and the world is full of case studies to prove them wrong. Applied creativity can be as central, as integral and as functional as any operating system; and should be expected to be so.

And secondly - and this is where my exasperation shows itself: to misrepresent commercial creativity as just a bit of fancy window-dressing is hugely to underrate the talents of those who create it. To make entrancing things within the unforgiving discipline of a marketing brief is a very, very difficult thing to do; and all the more so, since it's often made to look so easy.

My colleague Juliette Garside is at the Shard and will report any major developments.

11.38am BST

The latest company to announce a flotation in the crowded market for initial public offerings (IPOs) is Spire, the private hospital group.

The company, owned by Cinven, the private equity firm, wants to raise £315m to reduce its debt and fund expansion. It is aiming for a stock market valuation of about £1bn, Reuters reported.

The company will publish its prospectus on 7 July and squeeze its float in later next month before the City heads for the beach in August.

The UK is heading for a record year for IPOs after the market spent years in the doldrums, but investors' enthusiasm for flotations is wearing thin after share falls by some high-profile IPO companies.

Fund managers are particularly wary of businesses floated by private equity firms unloading companies they were forced to hang on to during the long aftermath of the financial crisis.

Cinven will sell some of its existing shares to partly cash in on its investment but will keep a substantial stake in the business, Spire's chief executive Rob Roger told journalists.

Let's see if that commitment is enough to entice investors to stump up the cash.

Cinven created Spire when it bought Bupa's hospital business in 2007 for an enterprise value (which includes debt) of £1.4bn. It hasn't taken any money out of the company since and hasn't revealed the equity value of Spire at the time of its investment, according to Reuters.

11.12am BST

The CBI has published a disappointing retail sales survey for June. The balance of retailers reporting rising or falling sales fell to +4 from May's +16 and was well short of the +24 expected in a Reuters poll.

The CBI blamed weaker demand for food and clothing for slowing sales growth.

Barry Williams of Asda, who chairs the CBI's survey panel, said: "Slow wage growth continues to weigh on how much consumers are willing to go out and spend."

Steve Collins at London & Capital Asset Management points out that the survey has been unpredictable:

The CBI says the forward-looking part of the survey was more optimistic:

11.01am BST

The pound has fallen slightly as investors continue to grapple with Mark Carney's testimony to the Treasury committee yesterday.

webTitle: Stagecoach warns Scottish independence could hurt business

fields.standfirst: Transport firm led by major SNP donor tells shareholders public funding could dry up if Scots vote to leave the UK
fields.body:
Stagecoach, the sprawling transport group led by one of the Scottish National party's highest profile backers, has warned investors that September's independence referendum could hit the business.

Anti-independence campaigners seized on the warning given by the bus and train operator in its annual results, as the company's co-founder and chairman, Sir Brian Souter, is a major donor of the SNP and supporter of independence.

Souter, who ran the Perth-based group as chief executive until May 2013, recently gave £100,000 to fringe group Christians for Independence and promised to match up to £1m-worth of donations to the SNP's referendum campaign.

However, in the "principal risks and uncertainties" section of the report, the company states: "There is a risk that changes to the regulatory environment or changes to the availability of public funding could affect the Group's prospects. Such changes may arise as a result of the outcomes of the September 2014 referendum on Scottish independence and/or the 2015 UK general election."

Ian Murray, Labour's shadow business minister in the Commons and a spokesman for the Better Together campaign, said the passage had driven "a coach and horses" through the case for independence.

"Being part of the UK single market works well for firms like Stagecoach," Murray said. "Scottish employers have access to a market of more than 63 million people across the UK, rather than just 5 million people in Scotland. Where is the sense in putting up barriers between Scottish firms and their customers based elsewhere in the UK?"

webTitle: WPP shareholders revolt over plan that gave Martin Sorrell £30m windfall

fields.standfirst: About 30% of investors reject plan that will see ad giant's boss collect £100m in share awards for next three years
fields.body:
WPP shareholders have again rebuked the British advertising giant over remuneration, with nearly 30% refusing to endorse a plan that ensured founder Sir Martin Sorrell was the best paid executive in the FTSE 100 last year with a £30m windfall.

The vote at Wednesday's annual shareholder meeting suggests that departing WPP chairman Philip Lader has yet to quell a rebellion that began in 2012. In arrangements described by the influential advisory group Pirc as excessive, Sorrell is expected to collect nearly £100m over the next three years in share awards from long term schemes that were halted in 2012 but have yet to expire.

In addition, he will be entitled to earn a maximum of £19.3m a year in 2014 and 2015, under a new scheme introduced last year.

Votes cast before the meeting at London's Shard skyscraper showed over 28% of shareholders rejected or abstained from approving the 2013 pay plan, up from 26% the year before. In a separate poll on the three year pay policy introduced in 2013, the first binding vote under new city rules, 26% voted against or abstained.

However, in order to pass a resolution, companies need a simple majority of votes cast, and WPP secured approval from nearly 82% of shareholders excluding abstentions for its pay policy.

"There have been some considerable concessions about executive remuneration at WPP over the last few years but the company still maintains a complex assortment of pay arrangements," said Pirc representative Andrew Whiley at the meeting. "Will the board consider making all of the variable pay arrangements much more simple, transparent, and easier for shareholders to get a handle on?"

Because WPP has not cancelled legacy pay schemes, which will make up the bulk of Sorrell's earnings over the coming years, Pirc argues the company is running six separate plans, all of which have different rules.

Awards under WPP's contentious leadership equity acquisition plan (Leap) will continue until 2016. This is because the scheme ran until 2012, but executives are not able to claim their shares for five years. By 2016, Sorrell is expected to receive 7.8m shares from Leap, worth £97.5m at today's £12.52 share price.

Lader responded: "We admit complexity but hope you see our commitment to transparency," adding that cancelling earlier plans would be unfair and could raise legal issues.

Private shareholder Keith Jago took the floor at the meeting to say Sorrell's £30m earnings last year were equivalent to £24,000 for every working hour. He also questioned the chief executive's benefits, which included a £167,000 travel allowance for his wife Cristiana Sorrell, an organiser of the World Economic Forum at Davos.

"I wonder how anyone can be wroth £30m when the UK is debating over minimum wage levels," said Jago. He also questioned the company's tax haven registration in Jersey. "Personally I don't want to be part of a company that behaves like that. Are we of the same ilk as Amazon or Starbucks?"

WPP paid £240m around the world in corporation tax last year, according to finance director Paul Richardson, and over £150m in the UK in various taxes. Following the collapse of a merger between American rival Omnicom and France's Publicis, WPP remains by some margin the largest marketing group in the world, accounting for at least a quarter of global media spend.

Sorrell pointed out that £1000 invested when the company was founded in 1985 would be wroth £47,900 today. The same sum invested in the FTSE 250 over that period would be worth just £4,250. He said WPP had enriched institutional investors and pension funds by £18bn during its lifetime as a listed company.

Scottish Widows, the third largest shareholder with 2.5% and a leading voice in previous revolts, is understood to have backed the board this year. Blackrock, the second-largest investor with 3.5%, and Legal & General are understood to have supported the pay policy.

The Local Authority Pension Fund Forum, which represents 60 public sector retirement funds, advised its members to vote against. The forum's chair Kieran Quinn said: "Overall, it is excessive and does not have our support … The Forum will continue to highlight examples of where senior leadership of large corporations seek complex salary and bonus packages that are not justified by performance and are out of step with shareholder and community expectations of reasonable reward for effort."

webTitle: US GDP fall: what the economists say

fields.standfirst: The country's economy shrank at an annual rate of 2.9% in the first three months of 2014, but most economists are positive about the outlook ahead
fields.body:
The US economy shrank at an annual rate of 2.9% in the first three months of 2014 – its fastest fall since the depths of the recession five years ago, as the harsh winter took a far bigger toll on activity than previously estimated.

James Knightley, economist at ING

"US first quarter GDP has been revised lower by far than expected. After having initially been reported as a 0.1% rise, then a 1% contraction, the third release shows that GDP growth is now reported as -2.9% quarter on quarter, annualised, which leaves annual growth at just 1.5% year on year. The consensus expectation was for a -1.8% reading.

"The damage was largely done through the private consumption component, which is now reported as rising just 1% versus 3.1% previously. Gross private investment remained an 11.7% contraction while government consumption was left at -0.8%. However, exports were revised down and imports revised up meaning that the contribution from net trade is to subtract 1.5% from GDP growth rather than 0.95% as previously announced.

"Nonetheless, reaction should be fairly muted given widespread expectations of a sharp bounceback in the second quarter of 2014 and the fact that the weather had such a damaging impact on first quarter activity. Indeed, we suspect that we could see GDP rise by more than 5% annualised in 2Q."

Gus Faucher, senior economist at PNC Financial Services

"The contraction in the first quarter is old news, and things are looking much better for the rest of this year. Most importantly the labour market remains solid. Firms have added more than 200,000 jobs per month on average so far in 2014, even with the first quarter contraction, and there are no signs that hiring is letting up. This is more than enough to bring down the unemployment rate, and households are feeling more confident about the labour market. Job gains are allowing households to increase their spending, with higher stock prices and home values also helping.

"Recent data have been solid, with big jumps in new and existing home sales in May, and consumer confidence recovering after it took a hit in the winter. An expanding global economy will help boost exports. And government will be neutral for growth, after being a drag for most of the past few years. PNC is forecasting growth of 4% in the second quarter, with a big boost from inventories, and then growth of about 3% in the second half of 2014."

Paul Dales, senior US economist, Capital Economics

"Despite the 2.9% annualised contraction in US GDP in the first quarter, more up-to-date data show that activity is rebounding in the second quarter. Indeed, May's durables goods orders suggest that business investment is growing again.

"The larger contraction in GDP in the first quarter is not a sign that the US is suffering from a fundamental slowdown - it was still largely due to the extreme weather. The latest data are consistent with growth in the second quarter rebounding to at least 3%."

Nancy Curtin, chief investment officer, Close Brothers Asset Management

"The US economy did not just grind to a halt in the first quarter – it hit reverse as the polar vortex took its toll. But we can not judge current growth by looking in the rearview mirror and we are unlikely to see investors react strongly to what is now quite a long way behind us.

"More recent data have pointed to the economy picking up speed. Manufacturing is at a four year high, while the housing market is looking positive once more. It is clear that growth gone up through the gears in second quarter and we'll see this reflected in the next GDP reading."

webTitle: US economy shrinks at fastest rate since recession as harsh winter bites

fields.bodyText: The US economy has shrunk at its fastest rate since the depths of the recession five years ago as it emerged that the harsh winter took a far bigger toll on activity than previously estimated. Official data released in Washington showed that output as measured by gross domestic product fell at an annual rate of 2.9% in the first three months of 2014. But the much worse than expected performance was shrugged off by Wall Street, where shares were up in early trading amid confidence that the economy bounced back strongly once the weather improved in the spring. Optimism was boosted by the latest snapshot of the US service sector that showed the sharpest increase in activity since the survey began four and a half years ago. Earlier traders in New York had been taken unawares when the Department of Commerce published its third estimate of US first quarter growth. Originally, it was thought output had increased by 0.1% at an annual rate in the quarter ending March but this was adjusted to a 1% decline at the second reading. The gap between the second and the third estimates was the largest on record, with the consensus on Wall Street for growth to be revised down to a annualised fall of 1.7%. Officials at the commerce department said the downward revision to growth had been the result of lower consumer spending on health care and a weaker than previously estimated contribution from exports. Nancy Curtin, the chief investment officer of Close Brothers Asset Management said: "The US economy didn't just grind to a halt in the first quarter – it hit reverse as the polar vortex took its toll. But we can't judge current growth by looking in the rear-view mirror, and we are unlikely to see investors react strongly to what is now quite a long way behind us. "More recent data have pointed to the economy picking up speed. Manufacturing is at a four year high, while the housing market is looking positive once more. It's clear that growth has gone up through the gears in the second quarter, and we'll see this reflected in the next GDP reading." Gautam Batra, Investment Strategist at Signia Wealth, said: "The bad weather will have played its part, but the figures also raise questions about the efficacy of the Federal Reserve's quantitative easing programme in creating a sustained economic recovery. The Fed faces headwinds to its monetary policy strategy with a cocktail of growing inflationary pressure and weaker than expected economic traction."

webTitle: Retail sales growth falls to lowest level since January

fields.bodyText: Sunny weather and the fanfare surrounding the World Cup failed to persuade shoppers to open their wallets in the month to June, with retail sales growth falling to its lowest level since January. According to the latest CBI barometer of retail sales, buoyant growth during spring and early summer has given way to a markedly less rosy picture as shoppers react to persistently low pay rises and the threat of higher mortgage rates later this year. After a recent improved run for the high street, a fall in clothing and food sales dragged down growth, the survey found. The results follow a pattern set by official figures for retail sales in May, which showed that shoppers were generally unwilling to spend after a spree in March and April. The CBI found that the balance of the number of retailers reporting that their sales were up year-on-year retreated markedly to a seven-month low of +4% in June from +16% in May and +30% in April. The Office for National Statistics found that the volume of retail sales fell 0.5% in May, compared with a 1% increase in April as consumers stocked up on goods for Easter. Howard Archer, chief UK economist at IHS Global Insight, said some correction in retails sales was always likely in May after they were lifted in April by the late Easter, but they had been expected to pick up in June with the help of the World Cup. "Hopefully, this will turn out to be just a blip after sustained strong retail sales in recent months. Even so, the loss of momentum in retail sales does raise question marks as to how strong consumer spending can be until earnings growth picks up appreciably," he said. Wages only increased by 0.7% in May according to official figures, well below the rate of inflation, which in May fell to a five-year low of 1.5%. Consumers are also becoming increasingly wary of rising interest rates, despite conflicting messages from the Bank of England on when rates might start to go up. The latest Markit household finances survey showed a huge jump in expectations of an interest rate rise, with 60% of respondents preparing for a rise from the current 0.5% in the next six months, compared with only 30% the previous month. Archer said the falls should not be overplayed and that the latest hard data showed underlying strength in retail sales, while the CBI survey revealed retailers were relatively upbeat over sales prospects with a balance of +17% expecting their sales to be up year-on-year in July. Barry Williams, the chair of the CBI's survey panel and Asda's chief merchandising officer for food, said: "While it seems that hopes retail spending would be boosted by a strong performance by England at the World Cup were as over-ambitious as aspirations for a good performance, I'm reassured that consumer confidence is still on the up, as household budgets are being bolstered by falling inflation. "However, whie discretionary income is still on the rise, slow wage growth continues to weigh on how much consumers are willing to go out and spend."

webTitle: Morrisons expands online food delivery across north London

fields.bodyText: Morrisons began expanding its online grocery service to the whole of north London on Wednesday in the struggling supermarket's latest bid to grab a share of the fast-growing online grocery market. The service is part of the supermarket chain's plan to turn around falling sales and profits by tapping into home deliveries and convenience stores as well as cutting thousands of prices to make it more competitive with discount supermarkets such as Aldi and Lidl. Morrisons finally launched its online grocery service, which operates via a partnership with specialist Ocado, in January 2014, more than a decade after most of its major rivals integrated e-commerce into their business. webTitle: RBS to face fury of investors at AGM over bonuses for bank bosses

fields.bodyText: Royal Bank of Scotland is expected to face shareholder attacks at its annual meeting on Wednesday after paying out £3.4bn in bonuses in the past four years. Executive pay and Scottish independence will be centre stage at the loss-making bank's meeting at its Gogarburn headquarters on the outskirts of Edinburgh. RBS, which is 80% taxpayer-owned after receiving a £45bn bailout during the financial crisis, doled out £1.4bn in bonuses in 2010, with payouts falling to £576m last year, according to the Robin Hood tax campaign, which represents 115 UK organisations including Friends of the Earth and the TUC. It is the first annual meeting for chief executive Ross McEwan, who was promoted to the top job last October after Stephen Hester quit. David Hillman of the Robin Hood tax campaign said: "When even a loss-making state-owned bank forks out billions in bonuses to its top brass it hammers home that bankers' pay is still out of touch with reality. Such vast sums could be put to better use tackling poverty and protecting public services. Unfortunately, the government often seems intent on defending the privileged elite in the City rather than ensuring they play a more productive role in society." After Treasury opposition, RBS had to ditch plans to pay its bankers bonuses twice the size of their salaries, but the government is not stopping the loss-making bank from handing executives payouts of up to 100% of pay. McEwan is in line for £1m a year in "share allowances" that sidestep the EU bonus cap and are also used by other banks. Shareholder group Pirc has advised investors to vote against RBS's pay policy. From 2014, executives will get up to 400% of salary through the share allowance and long-term incentives. "It is disappointing to see that the bank has found a way to circumvent the spirit" of the new EU rules, Pirc said. McEwan and RBS's chairman, Sir Philip Hampton, are also likely to face questions from shareholders over whether the bailed-out bank would move to England if Scotland votes for independence in September. Business secretary Vince Cable and Bank of England governor Mark Carney have suggested that RBS would have to relocate to London, sparking fears about 3,000 jobs at its Edinburgh base. An EU rule states banks must be based in the same country as most of their business. In the case of RBS, which owns NatWest and a London-based investment bank, this is England. RBS has not commented on a possible move but highlighted the risks from a Yes vote in its annual report, saying there could be a "material adverse effect" on its business and prospects and it would also affect its credit ratings. Shareholders are also likely to quiz RBS's bosses about lending to small businesses. RBS investors will also vote on whether to remove the dividend access scheme, which gives the government priority over payouts and is seen as an obstacle to privatisation. It will cost the bank £1.5bn to buy itself out of the scheme, but shareholders are likely to back the move. Analysts at Jefferies believe that RBS could reinstate dividends next year, with the float of its US business Citizens under way. A group of protesters plans to descend on the shareholder gathering to demand that RBS pull its money out of coal. Dressed as bankers, they will be handing out lumps of coal disguised as luxury chocolates ("fossil rochers") and holding placards reading "RBS out of coal". The World Development Movement claims RBS invests more in coal mining worldwide than any other UK bank.
